author: sky.cactus
content: I think I'm misunderstanding `RESERVE_GAS`.  If I have 10000 AA contracts that all do a `STATICCALL` into some contract `0xbaadf00d...` and read a variable (prior to `PAYGAS`), someone can set that variable such that all 10000 of those AA contracts are invalidated with a single external call.  How would you determine how much `RESERVE_GAS` is needed (in this case, we need to ensure it is 10,000 * minimum)?

author: samwilsn
content: `RESERVE_GAS` is for the other way around, when a non-AA transaction writes into an AA contract.

author: samwilsn
content: <@!301186049323958275> I updated the wording to make that more clear; thanks!

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!689161464829050960> With AA contracts able to do `STATIC_CALL` prior to `PAYGAS` though, you don't have to touch the AA contract in order to invalidate it.

author: samwilsn
content: AA contracts would still only be able to `DELEGATECALL` out. The changes here only permit static/limited non-static calls _into_ AA contracts.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, so there is still no plan for allowing AA contracts to call out?

author: samwilsn

author: m.kalinin

author: sky.cactus
content: I think that my problem with AA may be that I keep thinking about it from the standpoint of being able to do a bunch of interesting stuff before PAYGAS.  Really, I should be thinking about them just as normal contract with likely a single owner where the contract can pay for gas.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think that leaves me in a place where the only real change I would like to see is some kind of support for sponsored transactions.

author: samwilsn
content:
I don't think it's fair to say you can't do a bunch of interesting stuff before `PAYGAS`. Using zk proofs, multisig schemes, and all that are certainly interesting :P

All the restrictions are to ensure that once a transaction is valid, the only thing that can invalidate it is another transaction to the same contract.

author: sky.cactus
content: All of the things I think I have in my head for AA are really things that should happen *after* PAYGAS.

author: sky.cactus
content: The only requirement *prior* to PAYGAS is verifying that the transaction is valid *enough* to have the contract deduct gas fees.

author: sky.cactus
content: And in most cases that just means checking "is this data signed by a valid signer", which is unlikely to need to be looked up externally.
